docs.snippet: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 22 points, helping the Lakers gain a 107-98 victory over Washington and became the fourth-leading scorer in National Basketball Association history.    Abdul-Jabbar reached the milestone with 3:42 remaining in the first ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 22 points, helping the Lakers gain a 107-98 victory over Washington and became the fourth-leading scorer in National Basketball Association history. Abdul-Jabbar reached the milestone with 3:42 remaining in the first quarter when he made one of his patented skyhooks in the lane.

docs.snippet: HUGHES ALLISON'S ''The Trial of Dr. Beck,'' at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater is a theatrical oddity, a courtroom melodrama about eugenics, ''the science of improving the quality of the human race'' by means of ''a careful selec...
docs.lead_paragraph: HUGHES ALLISON'S ''The Trial of Dr. Beck,'' at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater is a theatrical oddity, a courtroom melodrama about eugenics, ''the science of improving the quality of the human race'' by means of ''a careful selection of parents.'' The play was first presented on Broadway in 1937 by the company's namesake, the W.P.A. Federal Theater, and has a minor significance in the history of black theater. In this play, his sole Broadway venture, Mr. Allison, a writer of detective fiction who died in 1974, combined an interest in law, biology and sociology. The scientific aspects of the case have faded into a kind of idiosyncratic polemicism, if not racism, but the legal side of the whodunit still retains a certain theatrical viability.

headline.main: STAGE: 'TRIAL OF DR. BECK' AT HENRY ST.

docs.snippet: AN adaptation of Robert Louis Stevenson's ''The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'' that makes Victorian London seem almost sexually trendy will be seen tonight and next Tuesday from 9 to 10 o'clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13.   This BBC product...
docs.lead_paragraph: AN adaptation of Robert Louis Stevenson's ''The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'' that makes Victorian London seem almost sexually trendy will be seen tonight and next Tuesday from 9 to 10 o'clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13. This BBC production, the premiere offering on this season's ''Mystery'' series, stars David Hemmings as the virtuous middle-aged physician who is able to transform himself into a much younger monster of depravity. With the exception of a murder or two, the details of Hyde's viciousness are scarcely alluded to in Stevenson's story. The three Hollywood film versions, which starred John Barrymore, Fredric March and Spencer Tracy, went further, but not as far as this latest retelling.

headline.main: TV: 'JECKYLL AND HYDE' AND A KARL MALDEN FILM

docs.snippet: The fashion trend that is most likely to succeed in the months ahead is that toward shorts: Walking shorts, which is what Bermudas are being called; flaring shapes, puffy shorts much like rompers or bloomers. Some are in silks, some in sturdy cott...
docs.lead_paragraph: The fashion trend that is most likely to succeed in the months ahead is that toward shorts: Walking shorts, which is what Bermudas are being called; flaring shapes, puffy shorts much like rompers or bloomers. Some are in silks, some in sturdy cottons. Some are casually tailored for day, others are frivolous and flippy and meant for evenings, especially evenings at home. These knee-baring designs are far more likely to win approval than skirts of the same length with their echoes of the 1960's, which older women swear they will never wear again and younger ones are too serious to attempt. The social climate has changed considerably from the rambunctious era in which the miniskirt flourished.

docs.snippet: Ever since Harry Baur appeared as Beethoven in a movie of the 1920's there have been films about classical musicians, most of them so bad as to enter some kind of unprintable category of their own; and ''The Competition,'' which opened last month,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since Harry Baur appeared as Beethoven in a movie of the 1920's there have been films about classical musicians, most of them so bad as to enter some kind of unprintable category of their own; and ''The Competition,'' which opened last month, is merely the latest in an ineffable line. Collectors dote on them, alternating between tears and hysterical laughter. Fortunately, it should be said at the outset, ''The Competition'' is better musically than most, and in the piano competition part of the film really tries hard to come to grips with the phenomenon. We all have our favorites. Mine was a thing called ''I've Always Loved You,'' which came out in 1946. This all-time low about serious music had a woman named Catherine McLeod as a pianist and someone named Philip Dorn as a conductor. He stood in front of an orchestra making gestures like a heavy pelican flapping its wings for a takeoff. As a pianist she was of the elbow-waving school, with her torso revolving around her neck. For this epic, none less than Artur Rubinstein played the sound-track.

headline.main: 'THE COMPETITION' STIRS MEMORIES OF MUSIC IN MOVIES

docs.snippet: Anyone who closely follows food journalism probably is aware that the popularity of certain dishes tends to run in cycles. The fashionable foods of the moment may be ''sophisticated'' recipes, such as quiche Lorraine, beef Wellington, gazpacho or ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who closely follows food journalism probably is aware that the popularity of certain dishes tends to run in cycles. The fashionable foods of the moment may be ''sophisticated'' recipes, such as quiche Lorraine, beef Wellington, gazpacho or ratatouille. Or they may be down-to-earth creations as homespun and tempting as carrot cake and zucchini bread. The latter, according to our observations, rank high on the current list of American favorites. In our own kitchen, we have recently tested the recipes for these tasty foods. The recipe for carrot cake is from ''My Mother Cooked My Way Through Harvard With These Creole Recipes'' by Oscar A. Rogers (University of Mississippi, Jackson, Miss., 1972). The recipe for zucchini bread is that of Shirley Estabrook Wood, an excellent cook in whose home we dined a couple of summers ago.

byline.original: By Craig Claiborne and Pierre Franey

docs.snippet: DIPPING INTO SPRINGTIME The soft curve of a shoulder, the subtle allure of a bare back, the daring of a plunging neckline - these are some of the traditional elements of evening clothes. For spring, many important American designers have combined ...
docs.lead_paragraph: DIPPING INTO SPRINGTIME The soft curve of a shoulder, the subtle allure of a bare back, the daring of a plunging neckline - these are some of the traditional elements of evening clothes. For spring, many important American designers have combined these ideas for up-to-date decolletages.

docs.snippet: If you've been yearning for a Calvin Klein jacket or a Ralph Lauren skirt or a Perry Ellis sweater that was priced slightly out of your reach, you may now be able to afford it. Department stores are having their end-of-season sales -and to one sho...
docs.lead_paragraph: If you've been yearning for a Calvin Klein jacket or a Ralph Lauren skirt or a Perry Ellis sweater that was priced slightly out of your reach, you may now be able to afford it. Department stores are having their end-of-season sales -and to one shopper they seem to be more extensive in scope and more dramatic in markdowns than in recent years. While most reductions are between 30 and 50 percent, some items can be found at one-third original price. There are two ways to approach clearance sales. Some people simply look for the best buy, even if it's something they weren't dying to own. Others set out with an idea in mind and search until they find it. For the latter, this rundown of what's around may save some precious shopping time.

docs.snippet: British students seem to favor the classics over today's best-sellers in what The Times of London calls a reassuring development - but a surprise.   In a survey to discover the favorite authors of 500 people applying for admission to the English d...
docs.lead_paragraph: British students seem to favor the classics over today's best-sellers in what The Times of London calls a reassuring development - but a surprise. In a survey to discover the favorite authors of 500 people applying for admission to the English department of London's University College, Thomas Hardy and Jane Austen beat John le Carre and Ian Fleming by a landslide. The suspense writers of today were far down the list, published by The Times, and authors of classics ranked high. The 10 authors mentioned most frequently were Thomas Hardy, by 194 applicants; Jane Austen, 165; D.H. Lawrence, 158; Charles Dickens, 124, the Bronte sisters, 106; George Orwell, 105; George Eliot, 69; James Joyce, 66; Graham Greene, 65, and Evelyn Waugh, 62.

headline.main: BRITAIN'S STUDENTS FAVOR CLASSICS, NOT BEST-SELLERS

docs.snippet: Lindsay Crouse took a cup of tea to ''the troll who lives upstairs''- her husband, David Mamet, the playwright - and settled back the other day in her old-timey Chelsea apartment to tell the story of her magical childhood. As she spoke, there was ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lindsay Crouse took a cup of tea to ''the troll who lives upstairs''- her husband, David Mamet, the playwright - and settled back the other day in her old-timey Chelsea apartment to tell the story of her magical childhood. As she spoke, there was the muffled pounding of Mr. Mamet's typewriter, a sound that is part of the texture of her life. Many of the people Miss Crouse has loved have been involved with writing, the theater, or both. She could have rejected it all, overwhelmed by the surfeit of talent in her household. Instead, she became an actress and married a playwright. Right now she is starring as Viola in the Circle Repertory's lighthearted version of Shakespeare's ''Twelfth Night,'' directed by Mr. Mamet. The critics have hailed her performance as ''outstanding,'' and said she exudes ''charm along with intelligence.''

headline.main: LINDSAY CROUSE KEEPS UP A FAMILY STAGE TRADITION
